com.appboy
Interface IAppboy

All Known Implementing Classes:
Appboy
public interface IAppboy

The public interface for the Appboy SDK. This interface is used to send and receive data to and from Appboy.

Overview

To use this class properly, follow the pattern below:
  1. Add your Appboy API key to your AndroidManifest.xml file.
  2. Create an IAppboy instance by calling Appboy.getInstance(android.content.Context).
  3. Call openSession(android.app.Activity) and closeSession(android.app.Activity) in your Activity's onStart() and onStop() respectively.
During the course of the application you may call Appboy.getInstance(android.content.Context) multiple times and with different Activities. Appboy uses the initial Activity that is passed in and grabs the Application context, which it then uses for the length of the process. 
   // Creating an IAppboy instance
   IAppboy appboy = Appboy.getInstance(this);
   
 
   // The Appboy API key is read from the AndroidManifest.xml file. Be sure to include the 'com.appboy.APPBOY_API_KEY'
   // (Constants.APPBOY_API_KEY) meta-data tag as a child of application element.
   <application android:icon="@drawable/icon" android:label="@string/app_name">
     <meta-data android:name="com.appboy.APPBOY_API_KEY" android:value="YOUR-API-KEY"/>
       ...
   </application>

Session Handling

It's imperative that you call IAppboy.openSession(Activity) and IAppboy.closeSession(Activity) in every Activity. Check your AndroidManifest.xml file for the list of Activities defined in your app and be sure to add these two method calls in the manner shown below. Forgetting to add them may result in incorrect session count and custom events will be ignored if there is no open session. 
   
   @Override
   public void onStart() {
     super.onStart();
     // Opens a new Appboy session.
     Appboy.getInstance(this).openSession(this);
   }

   @Override
   public void onStop() {
     // Closes the Appboy session.
     Appboy.getInstance(this).closeSession(this);
     super.onStop();
   }

Note: For methods which return a boolean, a value of true only indicates that the resulting asynchronous operation (posting feedback to the server, reporting a custom event, updating a user attribute, etc.) was requested. Any failures in execution will happen asynchronously and not be revealed by the return value. The SDK caches the data and tries to resend it automatically. Future versions of the SDK may expose these failures.

Method Detail

openSession

boolean openSession(android.app.Activity activity)
Opens a new session or resumes the previous session. A call to openSession(Activity) within 10 seconds of a call to closeSession(Activity) will cause the previous session to be resumed. This is done so that transitions from one Activity to another do not create a new session each time. This must be called in every Activity's onStart method.

Parameters:
activity - The current Activity.
Returns:
a boolean with the value of TRUE is a new session was created or FALSE is an existing session was resumed.

closeSession

boolean closeSession(android.app.Activity activity)
Closes the current session. The session may be reopened if a call is made to openSession(Activity) within 10 seconds. This must be called every the Activity's onStop method. Note: Android does not guarantee a total ordering of lifecycle methods, so in the event that the onStart() and onStop() lifecycle methods get called out of order, we treat the call to closeSession(Activity) as a no-op and return false.

Parameters:
activity - The current Activity.
Returns:
a boolean indicating whether or not an open session existed to close.

submitFeedback

boolean submitFeedback(java.lang.String replyToEmail,
                       java.lang.String message,
                       boolean isReportingABug)
Submits a piece of feedback to the Appboy feedback center so that it can be handled in the Appboy dashboard. The request to submit feedback is made immediately, however, this method does not block and will return as soon as the feedback request is placed on the network queue. Feedback submissions will also flush the session/events queue when the network request is actually made.

Parameters:
replyToEmail - The email address to send feedback replies to.
message - The message input by the user. Must be non-null and non-empty.
isReportingABug - Flag indicating whether or not the feedback describes a bug, or is merely a suggestion/question.
Returns:
a boolean indicating whether or not the feedback item was successfully queued for delivery.

logCustomEvent

boolean logCustomEvent(java.lang.String eventName)
Reports a custom named event.

Parameters:
eventName - The String identifier for the event to track. Best practice is to track generic events useful for segmenting, instead of specific user actions (i.e. track watched_sports_video instead of watched_video_adrian_peterson_td_mnf).
Returns:
a boolean indicating whether or not the event was successfully attached to the session (to be flushed later).

logPurchase

@Deprecated
boolean logPurchase(java.lang.String productId,
                               int priceInCents)
Deprecated. 

** DEPRECATED ** In order to log a purchase, switch to logPurchase(String productId, String currencyCode, BigDecimal price) and supply the appropriate currencyCode. The supported currency codes are: BRL, CAD, CZK, CHF, DKK, EUR, GBP, HKD, HUF, ILS, INR, JPY, KRW, MXN, NOK, NZD, PLN, RUB, SEK, SGD, TWD and USD. If you called logPurchase("product_id", 99) before, now you will call logPurchase("product_id", "USD", new BigDecimal("0.99")) Reports that the current user made an in app purchase. Useful for tracking and segmenting users more likely to make purchases.

Parameters:
productId - The String identifier for the product purchased. Usually the Google Play SKU.
priceInCents - The price paid. All calls to logPurchase should be normalized to a single currency for consistency in filtering across a user base.
Returns:
a boolean indicating whether or not the event was successfully attached to the session (to be flushed later).

logPurchase

boolean logPurchase(java.lang.String productId,
                    java.lang.String currencyCode,
                    java.math.BigDecimal price)
In order to log a purchase, switch to logPurchase(String productId, String currencyCode, BigDecimal price, int quantity). Using this method will by default log a purchase with a quantity of one.

See Also:
logPurchase(String, String, java.math.BigDecimal, int)

logPurchase

boolean logPurchase(java.lang.String productId,
                    java.lang.String currencyCode,
                    java.math.BigDecimal price,
                    int quantity)
Reports that the current user made an in app purchase. Useful for tracking and segmenting users more likely to make purchases.

Parameters:
productId - The String identifier for the product purchased. Usually the Google Play SKU.
currencyCode - Currencies should be represented as an ISO 4217 currency code. Supported currency symbols include: BRL, CAD, CZK, CHF, DKK, EUR, GBP, HKD, HUF, ILS, INR, JPY, KRW, MXN, NOK, NZD, PLN, RUB, SEK, SGD, TWD and USD. Any other provided currency symbol will result in a logged warning and no other action taken by the SDK.
price - The price paid. Base units depend on the currency. As an example, USD should be reported as Dollars.Cents, whereas JPY should be reported as a whole number of Yen. All provided BigDecimal values will have RoundingMode.HALF_UP rounding applied such that a maximum of two digits exist after the decimal point. Must be non-negative.
quantity - The quantity of items purchased expressed as a whole number. Must be greater than zero.
Returns:
a boolean indicating whether or not the event was successfully attached to the session (to be flushed later). Note: The productId and currencyCode are trimmed of any whitespace characters before being sent to Appboy. Note: Querying the Google Play store for SKU details may return the price of a in-app purchases in micros. Therefore, a purchase of price 0.99USD will be returned as 9900000. To pass this value to Appboy, be sure to convert it to a BigDecimal before attempting to convert it from micros to a decimal value in order to avoid integer division rounding errors. BigDecimal priceInMicro = new BigDecimal(9900000L); BigDecimal priceInDecimal = priceInMicro.divide(new BigDecimal(10e6));

logShare

boolean logShare(SocialNetwork network)
Reports that the current user shared activity to a social network. Useful for tracking and segmenting social media influencers.

Parameters:
network - The network which the share was made on. For shares to multiple networks, call this method multiple times.
Returns:
a boolean indicating whether or not the event was successfully attached to the session (to be flushed later).

logPushNotificationOpened

boolean logPushNotificationOpened(java.lang.String campaignId)
Reports that the user clicked on the push notification.

Parameters:
campaignId - The ID of the campaign that triggered the push notification. This can be found as an extra in the push notification intent.
Returns:
a boolean indicating whether or not the push notification click has been logged (to be flushed later).

logFeedDisplayed

boolean logFeedDisplayed()
Reports that the feed was displayed.

logFeedCardImpression

@Deprecated
boolean logFeedCardImpression(java.lang.String cardId)
Deprecated. 

** DEPRECATED ** Call the logFeedCardImpression method on the card object itself to log an impression. Reports a feed card was displayed to the user. Card impressions tracks how many times a card has been seen. Impressions should only be reported once the card becomes viewable to the user. Cards that are part of the stream but not visible should not log a card impression. If a card is viewed more than once in a particular view, it generates only one impression. If closed and reopened, a card will again generate an impression.

Parameters:
cardId - The ID of the feed card.

boolean logFeedCardClick(java.lang.String cardId)
Deprecated. 

** DEPRECATED ** Call the logFeedCardClick method on the card object itself to log a click. Reports a feed card was clicked.

Parameters:
cardId - The ID of the feed card.

logFeedbackDisplayed

boolean logFeedbackDisplayed()
Reports that the feedback form was displayed.

requestFeedRefresh

void requestFeedRefresh()
Requests an immediate refresh of the news feed from the Appboy server. All refresh requests also flush the session/events queue when the network request executes. Results of refresh calls are reported asynchronously via events. Events can be subscribed to with other methods in this class. If the network call returns before any subscribers are active, the result will be lost.

requestSlideupRefresh

void requestSlideupRefresh()
Requests an immediate refresh of only the slideup. Use this if you want to check for new slideup messages, but don't want to incur the overhead of pulling down an entire new message feed. All refresh requests also flush the session/events queue when the network request is actually made. Results of refresh calls are reported asynchronously via events. Events can be subscribed to with other methods in this class. If the network call returns before any subscribers are active, the result will be lost.

requestFeedRefreshFromCache

void requestFeedRefreshFromCache()
Requests a refresh of the news feed from offline storage. The result of this call will be reported asynchronously via a FeedUpdatedEvent, similar to a call to requestFeedRefresh().

requestImmediateDataFlush

void requestImmediateDataFlush()
Requests an immediate flush of any analytics data waiting to be sent to Appboy's servers.

subscribeToFeedUpdates

void subscribeToFeedUpdates(IEventSubscriber<FeedUpdatedEvent> subscriber)
Subscribes to a news feed event. The subscriber callback will be called when the news feed is updated. The subscriber will be called with a FeedUpdatedEvent. Subscriptions should be cleaned up manually by calling removeSingleSubscription(com.appboy.events.IEventSubscriber, Class). All events are triggered from background threads and isolate any encountered exceptions. If you need to do work on the UI thread in response to an event, you will need to coordinate that in the IEventSubscriber's trigger method.

Parameters:
subscriber - A callback that should be executed when the news feed is updated.

subscribeToNewSlideups

void subscribeToNewSlideups(IEventSubscriber<SlideupEvent> subscriber)
Subscribes to a news Slideup event. The subscriber callback will be called when the a new slideup is sent. The subscriber will be called with a SlideupEvent. Subscriptions should be cleaned up manually by calling removeSingleSubscription(com.appboy.events.IEventSubscriber, Class). All events are triggered from background threads and isolate any encountered exceptions. If you need to do work on the UI thread in response to an event, you will need to coordinate that in the IEventSubscriber's trigger method.

Parameters:
subscriber - A callback that should be executed when the news feed is updated.

subscribeToFeedbackRequestEvents

void subscribeToFeedbackRequestEvents(IEventSubscriber<SubmitFeedbackSucceeded> submitFeedbackSucceededSubscriber,
                                      IEventSubscriber<SubmitFeedbackFailed> submitFeedbackFailedSubscriber)
Subscribes to a events fired as a result of a submitFeedback(String, String, boolean) request. The submitFeedbackSucceededSubscriber callback will be called if the feedback has been successfully sent to and processed by Appboy. The submitFeedbackFailedSubscriber callback will be called if the feedback has been unsuccessfully processed by Appboy. The subscriber contains details of the error. Subscriptions should be cleaned up manually by calling removeSingleSubscription(com.appboy.events.IEventSubscriber, Class). All events are triggered from background threads and isolate any encountered exceptions. If you need to do work on the UI thread in response to an event, you will need to coordinate that in the IEventSubscriber's trigger method.

Parameters:
submitFeedbackSucceededSubscriber - A callback that should be executed if the feedback has been successfully processed.
submitFeedbackFailedSubscriber - A callback that should be executed if Appboy could not process the feedback

removeSingleSubscription

<T> void removeSingleSubscription(IEventSubscriber<T> subscriber,
                                  java.lang.Class<T> eventClass)
Removes a single subscription associated with the given activity and event class. This should be called if you want to selectively unsubscribe from an event, but do not want to remove every subscription for the activity.

Parameters:
subscriber - The callback which is currently subscribed.
eventClass - The Event class which this IEventSubscriber is subscribed to.

changeUser

AppboyUser changeUser(java.lang.String userId)
When you first start using Appboy on a device, the user is considered "anonymous". You can use this method to optionally identify a user with a unique ID, which enables the following: * If the same user is identified on another device, their user profile, usage history and event history will be shared across devices. * If your app is used by multiple people, you can assign each of them a unique identifier to track them separately. Only the most recent user on a particular device will receive push notifications and in-app messages. Any time you change from one user to another, you should explicitly request a feed and slideup refresh to receive fresh messaging content the new user. Even if you change from an anonymous user to an identified user locally, the messages could change because the now identified user could have a server side profile with segment membership different from the previously anonymous user. When you request a user switch (which is any call to changeUser where the new user ID is not the same as the existing user ID), the current session for the previous user (anonymous or not) is automatically sealed and a new session is started. Similarly, following a call to changeUser, any events which fire are guaranteed to be for the new user -- if an in flight server request completes for the old user after the user switch no events will fire, so you do not need to worry about filtering out events from Appboy for old users. Additionally, if you identify a user which has never been identified on another device, the entire history of that user as an "anonymous" user on this device will be preserved and associated with the newly identified user. However, if you identify a user which *has* been identified in another app, any history which was already flushed to the server for the anonymous user on this device will become orphaned and will not be associated with any future users. These orphaned users are not considered in your user counts and will not be messaged. As part of the user change process, if you switch from an identified user to another identified user, Appboy attempts to flush the previous user's with a background task. If that background task fails, Appboy will not attempt to re-flush the previous user's data until the next time you switch back to that user ID, instead preferring to minimize network traffic and free up any resources being used by the previous user's operations. When this method returns, all subsequent calls to your Appboy instance will operate on the new user, however, concurrent calls to other IAppboy methods are not in a forced order and thus could be on either the old or new user. For that reason, you should synchronize your calls to changeUser with other operations when in a multi-threaded environment. Note: Once you identify a user, you cannot revert to the "anonymous" user. The transition from anonymous to identified tracking is only allowed once because the initial anonymous user receives special treatment to allow for preservation of their history. As a result, we recommend against changing the user ID just because your app has entered a "logged out" state because it makes you unable to target the previously logged out user with re-engagement campaigns. If you anticipate multiple users on the same device, but only want to target one of them when your app is in a logged out state, we recommend separately keeping track of the user ID you want to target while logged out and switching back to that user ID as part of your app's logout process.

Parameters:
userId - An external user identifier
Returns:
the AppboyUser object representing the current active user after the change is complete.

getCurrentUser

AppboyUser getCurrentUser()
Returns the user currently being tracked by Appboy. Note that modifying values on instances of AppboyUser for a previous user will result in those values being stored locally, but they will not be synced with the Appboy server until that user becomes active again.

registerAppboyGcmMessages

@Deprecated
void registerAppboyGcmMessages(java.lang.String gcmRegistrationId)
Deprecated. 

DEPRECATED ** Use registerAppboyPushMessages(String)

Parameters:
gcmRegistrationId - The registration ID

registerAppboyPushMessages

void registerAppboyPushMessages(java.lang.String registrationId)
Registers the device as eligible to receive push notifications from Appboy. Appboy will use the provided GCM/ADM registration ID to send the device GCM/ADM messages. This should only be used if you already use GCM/ADM messaging in your app from another provider. Otherwise, set the com.appboy.APPBOY_GCM_MESSAGING_REGISTRATION_ENABLED/com.appboy.APPBOY_ADM_MESSAGING_REGISTRATION_ENABLED metadata attribute to "true" in the AndroidManifest.xml file to allow the Appboy SDK to handle the registration.

Parameters:
registrationId - The registration ID

unregisterAppboyPushMessages

void unregisterAppboyPushMessages()
Unregisters the device from receiving GCM/ADM push notifications from Appboy.

fetchAndRenderImage

void fetchAndRenderImage(java.lang.String imageUrl,
                         android.widget.ImageView imageView,
                         boolean respectAspectRatio)
Asynchronously fetches the image at imageUrl and renders it in imageView if imageView is still attached to that same URL when the image is available. Uses LRU memory and disc caching to minimize network traffic.

Parameters:
imageUrl - - The URL to the image resource.
imageView - - The ImageView to render the image in once it is downloaded or retrieved from cache.
respectAspectRatio - - When set to false, the aspect ratio of the imageView will match that of the downloaded image. When set to true, the imageView dimensions will remain unchanged, regardless of the actual dimensions of the downloaded image.

fetchAndRenderImage

void fetchAndRenderImage(java.lang.String imageUrl,
                         android.widget.ImageView imageView)
This method calls fetchAndRenderImage with respectAspectRatio set to false.

See Also:
fetchAndRenderImage(String, android.widget.ImageView, boolean)

getAppboyNavigator

IAppboyNavigator getAppboyNavigator()
Gets the current IAppboyNavigator class that defines the actions that should be taken when Appboy attempts to display the news feed or open a URI This will be null if none was set.

Returns:
The currently set IAppboyNavigator or null if none was set.

setAppboyNavigator

void setAppboyNavigator(IAppboyNavigator appboyNavigator)
Sets the class that defines the actions that should be taken when Appboy attempts to display the news feed or open a URI.

Parameters:
appboyNavigator - The IAppboyNavigator to use when attempting to display news feed or navigate to a URI.

getInstallTrackingId

java.lang.String getInstallTrackingId()
Returns a unique device ID for install tracking.
